body:
Hi @persas!

It's great that you would be willing to contribute! I'd recommend starting by reading our documentations on [MLmodels](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/models.html), especially the Storage Format, Model API, and Custom Flavors sections. After that, the next step would be to read the [CONTRIBUTING](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst) guide, which includes guidance on what we look for in contributions, the development practices. It also has some notes on [adding new model flavors](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst#adding-new-model-flavor-support).

Once you've done that - please let us know if you have further questions about how to approach the feature. If needed, I can pair you up with one of our developers to help you brainstorm the solution.

Hello Paul! I will walk through the documents and let you know if I have
any questions.

However, I would love some more specific guidance since this will be my
first time contributing, very excited about that!

Please, let me know what are the next steps.

Thank you so much in advance!

Best!

El vie., 1 may. 2020 a las 20:52, Paul Ogilive (<notifications@github.com>)

Hi @persas! More than happy to answer any specific questions you have about Model Flavor development. As a reference, I would recommend taking a look at a recent pull request that introduced an XGBoost flavor to MLflow: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/pull/2124. In particular, the `mlflow/xgboost.py` implements the new flavor logic and APIs (i.e., `log_model`, `save_model`, `load_model`, and `get_default_conda_env()`. We also recommend introducing a Gensim flavor example once the feature has been implemented (see https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/pull/2186 for reference about how to write examples for new flavors).

cc @dmatrix for input about documenting new flavors, introducing code snippets, and adding examples

Hi @dbczumar 

I was coding the gensim flavor, but it has some particularities and those are the ones I want to address with you.

In particular, gensim has many different models ([gensim.models](https://github.com/RaRe-Technologies/gensim/tree/develop/gensim/models)).

Models such as, Doc2Vec, Word2Vec, or tfidf are very popular within the NLP community. Regarding the flavor itself, saving models will be exactly the same, but loading them will depend on which "sub-flavor" of gensim you saved. 

 At this point I think it make sense to have them all as a single gensim flavor, but please, let me know if there is a similar flavor and how to approach the best solution

@persas 
That seems reasonable to encode them all in a single flavor. We do that for other libraries with many different model types, such as scikit-learn.
Nice! I will take scikit learn as example for coding! Thank you :)

Hello!!

I have submitted a PR: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/pull/2878 a few
weeks ago with no response. Do you know what is the actual procedure for
this? I might did something wrong and I don't know what.

Thanks!
